section.title: Overview
section.para: Reef uses the AMQP () for transport and Google Protocol Buffers () to serialize messages. The combination of these two technologies comprise the interface to the Reef service layer. Bindings can be created for any platform/language with a compatible AMQP client and a Protobuf compiler. Reef is factored as a RESTful service oriented architecture (SOA).

Since Reef runs on the JVM, the reference implementation for the client binding is written for Java. The client API handles details of maintaining a connection to an AMQP broker, routing service requests to their named AMQP exchanges, providing the asynchronous delivery of service message events, and building the proper request headers.
For the user, the client API involves the management of two central objects: Connection and Session.

listitem.para: Connection: Maintains a connection to the AMQP broker, handles the threading of asynchronous communication, acts as a Session factory. The underlying implementation extends the IConnection interface.
Session: Used by a single thread at a time, provides methods for making service requests. Users interact with the ISession interface.

section.para: Implementations of IConnection must be thread-safe, but ISession must be used by only one thread at a time. The AMQP protocol itself fully allows for multiple concurrent sessions.

ISession interfaces represent long-lived objects that are associated one-to-one with underlying AMQP sessions.
Because there is a small cost associated with acquiring a new session, it is not recommended to use a new session per request. However, users should feel free to create as many sessions as needed to service their threading requirements. Recommended practice for multi-threaded applications is therefore to create an ISession per unit of concurrency, rather than synchronizing on a single session instance.

Some users, especially those writing server applications, may want to pool ISession instances in order to increase performance. In these cases, care must be taken to ensure the correct authorization is attached before any given request.
